Examined Line: The Art of Source Code Analysis with Sokrates

Intro

  •  

    Background: Sokrates Philosophy

    Sokrates is an experimental tool that I have build both as a way to deal with issues in my daily practice, as well as to explore how far a person can go by following a simple approach to building code analysis tools.
  •  

    Using Sokrates

    In a nutshell, Sokrates is a exploration and feedback giving tool, that can help you to understand you code, reflect and discuss its findings, and take actions based on the findings.

  • Configuring and Scoping

     

    Sokrates Configuration File

    Sokrates analyses take two inputs:

    • the actual source code, including all folders and files, and
    • a configuration file, which describes how Sokrates should view and analyze the source code.
  •  

    Scoping

    When analyzing source code, you need to be strict in what you want to analyze and reject the rest. Otherwise, you will also end up publishing big, complex, and useless reports. The code that developers wrote manually is the most important. It contains critical content for understanding the system's unique structure, logic, and team's design decisions.
  •  

    Logical Decompositions

    Logical decomposition is a representation of, or a view on the organization of the main source code. In such a view every and each file is put in exactly one logical component.
  •  

    Cross-Cutting Concerns

    Cross-cutting concerns are aspects of a software system that cannot be cleanly decomposed from the rest of the system.

  • Sokrates' Analyses

     

    Sokrates Analysis Overview

    Sokrates analysis approach consists of the following mechanisms:
  •  

    Code Cleaning

    “Storms don’t come to teach us painful lessons, rather they were meant to wash us clean.” - Socrates
  •  

    File-Level Measurements: File Size

    Project-Based Measurements
  •  

    File-Level Measurements: History

    File change analysis takes as an input the list of dates on which source code files changes, and analyses these dates to understand how frequently developers have changed the files, how old are the files they, and how recently developers have updated them.
  •  

    Unit-Level Measurements

    Most of Sokrates’ analyses are at the level of a whole file. Sokrates also goes a level deeper, at a so-called unit level.
  •  

    Finding Dependencies based on Text Patterns

    “And a thing is not seen because it is visible, but conversely, visible because it is seen” ― Socrates
  •  

    Finding Dependencies through Duplication and Change History

    In the previous section, we discussed a typical way to find dependencies among source code components. There, developers, through import or include statements, explicitly declare that some file depends on some other piece of code. To find dependencies, we then need to locate these statements and process them to identify a referenced component.
  •  

    Duplication Analysis

    Analyzing Duplication
  •  

    Aggregating Measurements

    Through aggregation, Sokrates generates new summary views on data.
  •  

    Metrics Table

    Sokrates metrics is a one-dimensional list of key value pairs. Severla conventions.
  •  

    Controls

    IN Sokrates you can define traffic lights like controls. For each of the metrics that Sokrates measures, you can specify a control with the threshold and tolerance. Sokrates will then generate a report labeling each control with one of the following states:

    • OK (green) the measured value is below the threshold
    • tolerant (yellow) the measured value is above the threshold but within the tolerance range
    • failed (red), the measured value is above the threshold and the tolerance level.
  •  

    Trend Analysis

    Trend analysis shows the difference between values measured at different times, comparing the results of the current analysis with previous reports.
  •  

    Landscape Analysis

    Landscape analysis aggregates and indexes the results from multiple Sokrates projects.

  • Appendixes

     

    Appendix: Regular Expressions

    Jeff Atwood, the co-founder of StackOverflow.com, is a big fan of regular expressions. On a shortlist of his mandatory readings for software engineering is the Regular Expression Cookbook, and this is what he says:
  •  

    Appendix: Sokrates String Transformation Language (SSTL)

    The Sokrates String Transformation Language (SSTL) is a simple embedded programming language enabling you to transform a phrase extracted from a file path or file content into another string.
